abstract: Walt Disney Company said it had agreed to buy Marvel Entertainment, the storied comic book company that owns the rights to such popular characters as Spider Man and and the Fantastic Four, in a cash and stock deal it valued at $4 billion.
snippet: Walt Disney Company said it had agreed to buy Marvel Entertainment, the storied comic book company that owns the rights to such popular characters as Spider Man and and the Fantastic Four, in a cash and stock deal it valued at $4 billion.
lead_paragraph: Update | 9:48 a.m.  Mickey Mouse, meet Iron Man.

headline.main: Disney to Buy Marvel Entertainment for $4 Billion

abstract: Disney’s acquisition of Marvel Entertainment will also add Spider-Man and Captain America to its array of businesses.
snippet: Disney’s acquisition of Marvel Entertainment will also add Spider-Man and Captain America to its array of businesses.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company’s surprise deal to acquire Marvel Entertainment for $4 billion redraws the architecture of Hollywood and spotlights how the media giant has become more aggressive than its peers about growth.

headline.main: Disney Swoops Into Action, Buying Marvel for $4 Billion
headline.print_headline: Disney Swoops Into Action, Buying Marvel For $4 Billion

byline.original: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

abstract: Disney’s friendly deal to buy Marvel Entertainment makes it easy to forget that the comic-book company’s takeover history has a dark side: In the late 1990s, Ronald O. Perelman was grappling with Carl C. Icahn for control of Marvel.
snippet: Disney’s friendly deal to buy Marvel Entertainment makes it easy to forget that the comic-book company’s takeover history has a dark side: In the late 1990s, Ronald O. Perelman was grappling with Carl C. Icahn for control of Marvel.
lead_paragraph: As Walt Disney announced its friendly, $4 billion deal to buy Marvel Entertainment on Monday, complete with upbeat quotes from top executives, it was easy to forget that the comic book company’s deal-making history has a dark side.

abstract: Stan Lee thinks the Disney/Marvel deal is just great.
snippet: Stan Lee thinks the Disney/Marvel deal is just great.
lead_paragraph: Stan Lee, a former Marvel executive and a co-creator of Spider-Man, among other superheroes, is a proud papa these days, seeing that Disney values his characters enough to pay $4 billion for them. Mr. Lee, whose complicated relationship with Marvel has included multiple court battles, released the following statement through a publicist:

headline.main: Stan Lee Thinks the Disney-Marvel Deal Is Just Great
